an8.62:1.1.pli: “Chahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a mendicant with six qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.62:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:1.3.eng: A mendicant is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:1.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:1.5.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:1.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:1.7.pli: kalyāṇavāco ca hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo, poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:1.7.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.62:1.8.pli: sandassako ca hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:1.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:1.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, chahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:1.9.eng: A mendicant with these six qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.62:2.1.pli: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:2.1.eng: A mendicant with five qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.62:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:2.3.eng: A mendicant is not quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:2.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:2.5.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:2.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:2.7.eng: They’re a good speaker. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.62:2.8.pli: sandassako ca hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:2.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:2.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano alaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:2.9.eng: A mendicant with these five qualities is good enough for themselves and others.

an8.62:3.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:3.1.eng: A mendicant with four qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:3.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:3.3.eng: A mendicant is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:3.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:3.5.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:3.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:3.7.pli: no ca kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo, poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:3.7.eng: But they’re not a good speaker and do not enunciate well. Their voice isn’t polished, clear, articulate, and doesn’t express the meaning.

an8.62:3.8.pli: no ca sandassako hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:3.8.eng: They don’t educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:3.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:3.9.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:4.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ nālaṃ attano.
an8.62:4.1.eng: A mendicant with four qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.

an8.62:4.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:4.3.eng: A mendicant is quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:4.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:4.5.pli: no ca dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthūpaparikkhitā hoti;
an8.62:4.5.eng: But they don’t examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:4.6.pli: na ca atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti;
an8.62:4.6.eng: Not understanding the meaning and the teaching, they don’t practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:4.7.pli: kalyāṇavāco ca hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo …pe… atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:4.7.eng: They’re a good speaker who enunciates well. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.62:4.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:4.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ, nālaṃ attano.
an8.62:4.9.eng: A mendicant with these four qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.

an8.62:5.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:5.1.eng: A mendicant with three qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:5.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;

an8.62:5.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:5.5.eng: They examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:5.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:5.7.pli: no ca kalyāṇavāco hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo, poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:5.7.eng: But they’re not a good speaker and do not enunciate well. Their voice isn’t polished, clear, articulate, and doesn’t express the meaning.

an8.62:5.8.pli: no ca sandassako hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:5.8.eng: They don’t educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:5.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:5.9.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:6.1.pli: Tīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ, nālaṃ attano.
an8.62:6.1.eng: A mendicant with three qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.

an8.62:6.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:6.3.eng: A mendicant is not quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:6.4.eng: They readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:6.5.pli: no ca dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthūpaparikkhitā hoti;
an8.62:6.5.eng: But they don’t examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:6.6.pli: no ca atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti;
an8.62:6.6.eng: Not understanding the meaning and the teaching, they don’t practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:6.7.eng: They’re a good speaker. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.62:6.8.pli: sandassako ca hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:6.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:6.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ, nālaṃ attano.
an8.62:6.9.eng: A mendicant with these three qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.

an8.62:7.1.pli: Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:7.1.eng: A mendicant with two qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:7.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu na heva kho khippanisanti ca hoti kusalesu dhammesu;
an8.62:7.3.eng: A mendicant is not quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:7.4.pli: no ca sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ dhāraṇajātiko hoti;
an8.62:7.4.eng: And they don’t readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:7.5.eng: But they examine the meaning of teachings they have memorized.

an8.62:7.6.eng: Understanding the meaning and the teaching, they practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:7.7.pli: no ca kalyāṇavāco hoti …pe… atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:7.7.eng: They’re not a good speaker. Their voice isn’t polished, clear, articulate, and doesn’t express the meaning.

an8.62:7.8.eng: They don’t educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:7.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ attano, nālaṃ paresaṃ.
an8.62:7.9.eng: A mendicant with these two qualities is good enough for themselves but not for others.

an8.62:8.1.pli: Dvīhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ, nālaṃ attano.
an8.62:8.1.eng: A mendicant with two qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.

an8.62:8.3.eng: A mendicant is not quick-witted when it comes to skillful teachings.

an8.62:8.4.pli: no ca sutānaṃ dhammānaṃ dhāraṇajātiko hoti;
an8.62:8.4.eng: And they don’t readily memorize the teachings they’ve heard.

an8.62:8.5.pli: no ca dhātānaṃ dhammānaṃ atthūpaparikkhitā hoti;
an8.62:8.5.eng: Nor do they examine the meaning of teachings they’ve memorized.

an8.62:8.6.pli: no ca atthamaññāya dhammamaññāya dhammānudhammappaṭipanno hoti;
an8.62:8.6.eng: Not understanding the meaning and the teaching, they don’t practice in line with the teaching.

an8.62:8.7.pli: kalyāṇavāco ca hoti kalyāṇavākkaraṇo, poriyā vācāya samannāgato vissaṭṭhāya anelagaḷāya atthassa viññāpaniyā;
an8.62:8.7.eng: But they’re a good speaker who enunciates well. Their voice is polished, clear, articulate, and expresses the meaning.

an8.62:8.8.pli: sandassako ca hoti samādapako samuttejako sampahaṃsako sabrahmacārīnaṃ.
an8.62:8.8.eng: They educate, encourage, fire up, and inspire their spiritual companions.

an8.62:8.9.pli: Imehi kho, bhikkhave, dvīhi dhammehi samannāgato bhikkhu alaṃ paresaṃ, nālaṃ attano”ti.
an8.62:8.9.eng: A mendicant with these two qualities is good enough for others but not for themselves.”

an8.63:1.1.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an8.63:1.1.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,

an8.63:1.2.pli: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ desetu, yamahaṃ bhagavato dhammaṃ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
an8.63:1.2.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief. When I’ve heard it, I’ll live alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute.”

an8.63:1.3.eng: “This is exactly how some futile people ask me for something.

an8.63:1.4.pli: Dhamme ca bhāsite mamaññeva anubandhitabbaṃ maññantī”ti.
an8.63:1.4.eng: But when the teaching has been explained they think only of following me around.”

an8.63:1.5.pli: “Desetu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṃ, desetu sugato saṅkhittena dhammaṃ. Appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājāneyyaṃ, appeva nāmāhaṃ bhagavato bhāsitassa dāyādo assan”ti.
an8.63:1.5.eng: “Sir, may the Buddha please teach me Dhamma in brief! May the Holy One teach me the Dhamma in brief! Hopefully I can understand the meaning of what the Buddha says! Hopefully I can be an heir of the Buddha’s teaching!”

an8.63:1.6.eng: “Well then, mendicant, you should train like this:

an8.63:1.7.pli: ‘ajjhattaṃ me cittaṃ ṭhitaṃ bhavissati susaṇṭhitaṃ, na ca uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā cittaṃ pariyādāya ṭhassantī’ti.
an8.63:1.7.eng: ‘My mind will be steady and well settled internally. And bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen will not occupy my mind.’

an8.63:2.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ajjhattaṃ cittaṃ ṭhitaṃ hoti susaṇṭhitaṃ, na ca uppannā pāpakā akusalā dhammā cittaṃ pariyādāya tiṭṭhanti, tato te, bhikkhu, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ:
an8.63:2.1.eng: When your mind is steady and well settled internally, and bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen don’t occupy your mind, then you should train like this:

an8.63:2.2.pli: ‘mettā me cetovimutti bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
an8.63:2.2.eng: ‘I will develop the heart’s release by love. I’ll cultivate it, make it my vehicle and my basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’

an8.63:3.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti bahulīkato, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, imaṃ samādhiṃ savitakkampi savicāraṃ bhāveyyāsi, avitakkampi vicāramattaṃ bhāveyyāsi, avitakkampi avicāraṃ bhāveyyāsi, sappītikampi bhāveyyāsi, nippītikampi bhāveyyāsi, sātasahagatampi bhāveyyāsi, upekkhāsahagatampi bhāveyyāsi.
an8.63:3.1.eng: When this immersion is developed and cultivated in this way, you should develop it while placing the mind and keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind or keeping it connected. You should develop it with rapture. You should develop it without rapture. You should develop it with pleasure. You should develop it with equanimity.

an8.63:4.1.pli: Yato kho, te bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti subhāvito, tato te, bhikkhu, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ:
an8.63:4.1.eng: When this immersion is well developed in this way, you should train like this:

an8.63:4.2.eng: ‘I will develop the heart’s release by compassion …’ …

an8.63:4.3.eng: ‘I will develop the heart’s release by rejoicing …’ …

an8.63:4.4.pli: upekkhā me cetovimutti bhāvitā bhavissati bahulīkatā yānīkatā vatthukatā anuṭṭhitā paricitā susamāraddhā’ti.
an8.63:4.4.eng: ‘I will develop the heart’s release by equanimity. I’ll cultivate it, make it my vehicle and my basis, keep it up, consolidate it, and properly implement it.’

an8.63:5.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti subhāvito, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, imaṃ samādhiṃ savitakkasavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkavicāramattampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkaavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, sappītikampi bhāveyyāsi, nippītikampi bhāveyyāsi, sātasahagatampi bhāveyyāsi, upekkhāsahagatampi bhāveyyāsi.
an8.63:5.1.eng: When this immersion is well developed in this way, you should develop it while placing the mind and keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind or keeping it connected. You should develop it with rapture. You should develop it without rapture. You should develop it with pleasure. You should develop it with equanimity.

an8.63:6.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti subhāvito, tato te, bhikkhu, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ:
an8.63:6.1.eng: When this immersion is well developed in this way, you should train like this:

an8.63:6.2.pli: ‘kāye kāyānupassī viharissāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan’ti.
an8.63:6.2.eng: ‘I’ll meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.’

an8.63:7.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti bahulīkato, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, imaṃ samādhiṃ savitakkasavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkavicāramattampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkaavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, sappītikampi bhāveyyāsi, nippītikampi bhāveyyāsi, sātasahagatampi bhāveyyāsi, upekkhāsahagatampi bhāveyyāsi.
an8.63:7.1.eng: When this immersion is developed and cultivated in this way, you should develop it while placing the mind and keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind or keeping it connected. You should develop it with rapture. You should develop it without rapture. You should develop it with pleasure. You should develop it with equanimity.

an8.63:8.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti subhāvito, tato te, bhikkhu, evaṃ sikkhitabbaṃ:
an8.63:8.1.eng: When this immersion is well developed in this way, you should train like this:

an8.63:8.2.eng: ‘I’ll meditate on an aspect of feelings …’ …

an8.63:8.3.eng: ‘I’ll meditate on an aspect of the mind …’ …

an8.63:8.4.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharissāmi ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassan’ti.
an8.63:8.4.eng: ‘I’ll meditate on an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.’

an8.63:9.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti bahulīkato, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, imaṃ samādhiṃ savitakkasavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkavicāramattampi bhāveyyāsi, avitakkaavicārampi bhāveyyāsi, sappītikampi bhāveyyāsi, nippītikampi bhāveyyāsi, sātasahagatampi bhāveyyāsi, upekkhāsahagatampi bhāveyyāsi.
an8.63:9.1.eng: When this immersion is developed and cultivated in this way, you should develop it while placing the mind and keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected. You should develop it without placing the mind or keeping it connected. You should develop it with rapture. You should develop it without rapture. You should develop it with pleasure. You should develop it with equanimity.

an8.63:10.1.pli: Yato kho te, bhikkhu, ayaṃ samādhi evaṃ bhāvito hoti subhāvito, tato tvaṃ, bhikkhu, yena yeneva gagghasi phāsuṃyeva gagghasi, yattha yattha ṭhassasi phāsuṃyeva ṭhassasi, yattha yattha nisīdissasi phāsuṃyeva nisīdissasi, yattha yattha seyyaṃ kappessasi phāsuṃyeva seyyaṃ kappessasī”ti.
an8.63:10.1.eng: When this immersion is well developed in this way, wherever you walk, you’ll walk comfortably. Wherever you stand, you’ll stand comfortably. Wherever you sit, you’ll sit comfortably. Wherever you lie down, you’ll lie down comfortably.”

an8.63:11.1.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu bhagavatā iminā ovādena ovadito uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṃ katvā pakkāmi.
an8.63:11.1.eng: When that mendicant had been given this advice by the Buddha, he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.

an8.63:11.2.pli: Atha kho so bhikkhu eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto nacirasseva—yassatthāya kulaputtā sammadeva agārasmā anagāriyaṃ pabbajanti, tadanuttaraṃ—brahmacariyapariyosānaṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja vihāsi.
an8.63:11.2.eng: Then that mendicant, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

an8.63:11.3.pli: “Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṃ brahmacariyaṃ, kataṃ karaṇīyaṃ, nāparaṃ itthattāyā”ti abbhaññāsi.
an8.63:11.3.eng: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

an8.63:11.4.pli: Aññataro ca pana so bhikkhu arahataṃ ahosīti.
an8.63:11.4.eng: And that mendicant became one of the perfected.

an8.64:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā gayāyaṃ viharati gayāsīse.
an8.64:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Gayā on Gayā Head.

an8.64:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:

an8.64:1.3.pli: “pubbāhaṃ, bhikkhave, sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno obhāsaññeva kho sañjānāmi, no ca rūpāni passāmi.
an8.64:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still not awake but intent on awakening—I perceived light but did not see forms.

an8.64:2.2.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ obhāsañceva sañjāneyyaṃ rūpāni ca passeyyaṃ;
an8.64:2.2.eng: ‘What if I were to both perceive light and see forms?

an8.64:2.3.pli: evaṃ me idaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ parisuddhataraṃ assā’ti.
an8.64:2.3.eng: Then my knowledge and vision would become even more purified.’

an8.64:3.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, aparena samayena appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi, rūpāni ca passāmi;
an8.64:3.1.eng: So after some time, living diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light and saw forms.

an8.64:3.2.pli: no ca kho tāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhāmi sallapāmi sākacchaṃ samāpajjāmi.
an8.64:3.2.eng: But I didn’t associate with those deities, converse, or engage in discussion.

an8.64:4.2.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ obhāsañceva sañjāneyyaṃ, rūpāni ca passeyyaṃ, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭheyyaṃ sallapeyyaṃ sākacchaṃ samāpajjeyyaṃ;
an8.64:4.2.eng: ‘What if I were to perceive light and see forms; and associate with those deities, converse, and engage in discussion?

an8.64:4.3.pli: evaṃ me idaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ parisuddhataraṃ assā’ti.
an8.64:4.3.eng: Then my knowledge and vision would become even more purified.’

an8.64:5.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, aparena samayena appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi, rūpāni ca passāmi, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhāmi sallapāmi sākacchaṃ samāpajjāmi;
an8.64:5.1.eng: So after some time … I perceived light and saw forms. And I associated with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.

an8.64:5.2.pli: no ca kho tā devatā jānāmi—

an8.64:5.3.pli: imā devatā amukamhā vā amukamhā vā devanikāyāti.
an8.64:5.3.eng: orders of gods those deities came from.

an8.64:6.2.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ obhāsañceva sañjāneyyaṃ, rūpāni ca passeyyaṃ, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭheyyaṃ sallapeyyaṃ sākacchaṃ samāpajjeyyaṃ, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ:
an8.64:6.2.eng: ‘What if I were to perceive light and see forms; and associate with those deities, converse, and engage in discussion;

an8.64:6.3.pli: “imā devatā amukamhā vā amukamhā vā devanikāyā”ti;
an8.64:6.3.eng: and find out which orders of gods those deities come from?

an8.64:6.4.pli: evaṃ me idaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ parisuddhataraṃ assā’ti.
an8.64:6.4.eng: Then my knowledge and vision would become even more purified.’

an8.64:7.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, aparena samayena appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi, rūpāni ca passāmi, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhāmi sallapāmi sākacchaṃ samāpajjāmi, tā ca devatā jānāmi:
an8.64:7.1.eng: So after some time … I perceived light and saw forms. And I associated with those deities … And I found out which orders of gods those deities came from.

an8.64:7.2.pli: ‘imā devatā amukamhā vā amukamhā vā devanikāyā’ti;

an8.64:7.3.pli: no ca kho tā devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:7.4.pli: ‘imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena ito cutā tattha upapannā’ti …pe…
an8.64:7.4.eng: deeds caused those deities to be reborn there after passing away from here.

an8.64:7.5.eng: So after some time … I found out what

an8.64:7.6.pli: ‘imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena ito cutā tattha upapannā’ti;
an8.64:7.6.eng: deeds caused those deities to be reborn there after passing away from here.

an8.64:7.7.pli: no ca kho tā devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:7.8.pli: ‘imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena evamāhārā evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvediniyo’ti …pe…
an8.64:7.8.eng: deeds caused those deities to have such food and such an experience of pleasure and pain.

an8.64:7.9.eng: So after some time … I found out what

an8.64:7.10.pli: ‘imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena evamāhārā evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvediniyo’ti;
an8.64:7.10.eng: deeds caused those deities to have such food and such an experience of pleasure and pain.

an8.64:7.11.pli: no ca kho tā devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:7.12.eng: these deities have a lifespan of such a length.

an8.64:7.13.eng: So after some time … I found out that

an8.64:7.14.eng: these deities have a lifespan of such a length.

an8.64:7.15.pli: no ca kho tā devatā jānāmi yadi vā me imāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ sannivutthapubbaṃ yadi vā na sannivutthapubbanti.
an8.64:7.15.eng: But I didn’t know whether or not I had previously lived together with those deities.

an8.64:8.2.pli: ‘sace kho ahaṃ obhāsañceva sañjāneyyaṃ, rūpāni ca passeyyaṃ, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭheyyaṃ sallapeyyaṃ sākacchaṃ samāpajjeyyaṃ, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ:
an8.64:8.2.eng: ‘What if I were to perceive light and see forms; and associate with those deities, converse, and engage in discussion;

an8.64:8.3.pli: “imā devatā amukamhā vā amukamhā vā devanikāyā”ti, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ:
an8.64:8.3.eng: and find out which orders of gods those deities come from;

an8.64:8.4.pli: “imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena ito cutā tattha upapannā”ti, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ:
an8.64:8.4.eng: and what deeds caused those deities to be reborn there after passing away from here;

an8.64:8.5.pli: “imā devatā evamāhārā evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvediniyo”ti, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ:
an8.64:8.5.eng: and what deeds caused those deities to have such food and such an experience of pleasure and pain;

an8.64:8.6.pli: “imā devatā evaṃdīghāyukā evaṃciraṭṭhitikā”ti, tā ca devatā jāneyyaṃ yadi vā me imāhi devatāhi saddhiṃ sannivutthapubbaṃ yadi vā na sannivutthapubbanti;
an8.64:8.6.eng: and that these deities have a lifespan of such a length; and whether or not I have previously lived together with those deities?

an8.64:8.7.pli: evaṃ me idaṃ ñāṇadassanaṃ parisuddhataraṃ assā’ti.
an8.64:8.7.eng: Then my knowledge and vision would become even more purified.’

an8.64:9.1.pli: So kho ahaṃ, bhikkhave, aparena samayena appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi, rūpāni ca passāmi, tāhi ca devatāhi saddhiṃ santiṭṭhāmi sallapāmi sākacchaṃ samāpajjāmi, tā ca devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:9.2.pli: ‘imā devatā amukamhā vā amukamhā vā devanikāyā’ti, tā ca devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:9.3.pli: ‘imā devatā imassa kammassa vipākena ito cutā tattha upapannā’ti, tā ca devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:9.4.pli: ‘imā devatā evamāhārā evaṃsukhadukkhappaṭisaṃvediniyo’ti, tā ca devatā jānāmi:

an8.64:9.5.pli: ‘imā devatā evaṃdīghāyukā evaṃciraṭṭhitikā’ti, tā ca devatā jānāmi yadi vā me devatāhi saddhiṃ sannivutthapubbaṃ yadi vā na sannivutthapubbanti.
an8.64:9.5.eng: I found out whether or not I have previously lived together with those deities.

an8.64:10.1.pli: Yāvakīvañca me, bhikkhave, evaṃ aṭṭhaparivaṭṭaṃ adhidevañāṇadassanaṃ na suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, neva tāvāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ.
an8.64:10.1.eng: As long as my knowledge and vision about the deities was not fully purified in these eight rounds, I didn’t announce my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an8.64:10.2.pli: Yato ca kho me, bhikkhave, evaṃ aṭṭhaparivaṭṭaṃ adhidevañāṇadassanaṃ suvisuddhaṃ ahosi, athāhaṃ, bhikkhave, ‘sadevake loke samārake sabrahmake sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya anuttaraṃ sammāsambodhiṃ abhisambuddho’ti paccaññāsiṃ;
an8.64:10.2.eng: But when my knowledge and vision about the deities was fully purified in these eight rounds, I announced my supreme perfect awakening in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans.

an8.64:10.3.eng: Knowledge and vision arose in me:

an8.64:10.4.pli: akuppā me cetovimutti; ayamantimā jāti natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
an8.64:10.4.eng: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”

an8.65:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight dimensions of mastery.

an8.65:1.3.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
an8.65:1.3.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.

an8.65:1.4.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:1.5.eng: This is the first dimension of mastery.

an8.65:2.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ rūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
an8.65:2.1.eng: Perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

an8.65:2.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:2.3.eng: This is the second dimension of mastery.

an8.65:3.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati parittāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
an8.65:3.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limited, both pretty and ugly.

an8.65:3.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:3.3.eng: This is the third dimension of mastery.

an8.65:4.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati appamāṇāni suvaṇṇadubbaṇṇāni.
an8.65:4.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, limitless, both pretty and ugly.

an8.65:4.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:4.3.eng: This is the fourth dimension of mastery.

an8.65:5.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati nīlāni nīlavaṇṇāni nīlanidassanāni nīlanibhāsāni.
an8.65:5.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, blue, with blue color and blue appearance.

an8.65:5.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:5.3.eng: This is the fifth dimension of mastery.

an8.65:6.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati pītāni pītavaṇṇāni pītanidassanāni pītanibhāsāni.
an8.65:6.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, yellow, with yellow color and yellow appearance.

an8.65:6.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:6.3.eng: This is the sixth dimension of mastery.

an8.65:7.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati lohitakāni lohitakavaṇṇāni lohitakanidassanāni lohitakanibhāsāni.
an8.65:7.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, red, with red color and red appearance.

an8.65:7.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:7.3.eng: This is the seventh dimension of mastery.

an8.65:8.1.pli: Ajjhattaṃ arūpasaññī eko bahiddhā rūpāni passati odātāni odātavaṇṇāni odātanidassanāni odātanibhāsāni.
an8.65:8.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, someone sees forms externally, white, with white color and white appearance.

an8.65:8.2.eng: Mastering them, they perceive: ‘I know and see.’

an8.65:8.3.eng: This is the eighth dimension of mastery.

an8.65:8.4.eng: These are the eight dimensions of mastery.”

an8.66:1.3.eng: Having physical form, they see forms.

an8.66:2.1.eng: Not perceiving form internally, they see forms externally.

an8.66:4.1.pli: Sabbaso rūpasaññānaṃ samatikkamā paṭighasaññānaṃ atthaṅgamā nānattasaññānaṃ amanasikārā ‘ananto ākāso’ti ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.66:4.1.eng: Going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the disappearance of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite space.

an8.66:5.1.pli: Sabbaso ākāsānañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘anantaṃ viññāṇan’ti viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.66:5.1.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, they enter and remain in the dimension of infinite consciousness.

an8.66:6.1.pli: Sabbaso viññāṇañcāyatanaṃ samatikkamma ‘natthi kiñcī’ti ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.66:6.1.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, they enter and remain in the dimension of nothingness.

an8.66:7.1.pli: Sabbaso ākiñcaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.66:7.1.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, they enter and remain in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an8.66:8.1.pli: Sabbaso nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ samatikkamma saññāvedayitanirodhaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an8.66:8.1.eng: Going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, they enter and remain in the cessation of perception and feeling.

an8.67:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight ignoble expressions.

an8.67:1.3.pli: Adiṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, asute sutavāditā, amute mutavāditā, aviññāte viññātavāditā, diṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, sute asutavāditā, mute amutavāditā, viññāte aviññātavāditā.
an8.67:1.3.eng: Saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, but you haven’t. And saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

an8.67:1.4.eng: These are the eight ignoble expressions.”

an8.68:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these eight noble expressions.

an8.68:1.3.pli: Adiṭṭhe adiṭṭhavāditā, asute asutavāditā, amute amutavāditā, aviññāte aviññātavāditā, diṭṭhe diṭṭhavāditā, sute sutavāditā, mute mutavāditā, viññāte viññātavāditā.
an8.68:1.3.eng: Saying you haven’t seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you haven’t. And saying you’ve seen, heard, thought, or known something, and you have.

an8.68:1.4.eng: These are the eight noble expressions.”
